title: This is regarding credit card Time Barred debt in California
question: 1) I have 3 credit cards Time Bared Debt in California and I would like to know that beside the 7 years negative credit report and the impact on my overall credit score what other economic repercussions of the time barred debt could I have if I buy a real estate property in the future?
answers:
I really don't have anything to add except to say I agree w/my colleague.
1. You may get a higher interest rate and not be able to bargain down. Sounds like you already know that.
2. No. Not unless you've done something to toll the statute - extend the statute - if you really haven't paid, haven't promised to pay, etc. and the debt is barred ... once barred, that's it.
3. No, except the 1099 my colleague mentions. Don't know what time limits are on 1099s - year forgiven? Not sure.
Best of luck!

1) If they don't already have a judgment against you, then no liens can ever attach to future-acquired property.
2) No.
3) You might be liable for the tax on that debt if you do not discharge it in BK before they send 1099-Cs to the IRS.

By "time barred debt" I assume you mean you believe the Statute of Limitations period has passed within which the creditor can file a civil lawsuit against you to collect the debt. According to California Code of Civil Procedure ยง 337(1), the statute of limitations for a written contract is four years. This means that after four years has passed since that last time you made any transactions using that account, the creditor can not successfully sue you in a California Court (assuming you appear in a civil suit to assert your rights). Be sure to calculate the statutory period correctly as it begins to run from the moment the borrower defaults on their payment, and may be extended or "refreshed" if you have made any transactions or payments toward that account (eg. "debt settlement" payments).
1) No, assuming you have correctly calculated the statute of limitations and the creditor has not filed a civil lawsuit against you before the statutory time period has lapsed;
2) No, but you can extend, renew or "refresh" the statutory period by your own actions relating to account;
3) Possibly, if the credit card company has issued you a 1099c before you are able to discharge the debt.
